name: nytimes
text: At the peak of the coronavirus pandemic in New York City, patients at some community hospitals were 3 times more likely to die as patients at medical centers in the wealthiest parts of the city, a New York Times investigation found https://t.co/bIxbvuylKV

name: nytimes
text: Underfunded hospitals in the neighborhoods hit the hardest had lower staffing, worse equipment and less access to advanced treatments at the height of the crisis, according to workers at all 47 of New York City’s general hospitals https://t.co/bIxbvuylKV https://t.co/XRomRrZZqM

name: nytimes
text: In one understaffed public hospital, at least 4 patients collapsed after removing their oxygen masks to go to the b… https://t.co/MxGP1lt5kF

name: nytimes
text: Emergency room nurses are supposed to care for a maximum of 4 patients at a time. During the height of the coronavirus pandemic, some hospitals in low-income parts of New York City had ratios of 20 to 1 — or higher. https://t.co/bIxbvuPWCt https://t.co/M6KVALdYd5

name: nytimes
text: It was another story at the prestigious medical centers in Manhattan, which have billions of dollars in endowments and cater largely to wealthy people with insurance. Their Covid-19 patients got access to heart-lung bypass machines and experimental drugs. https://t.co/bIxbvuylKV

name: nytimes
text: There are 5 hospital beds for every 1,000 residents in Manhattan, and only 1.8 beds per 1,000 residents in Queens.… https://t.co/XaESJle7Rb

name: nytimes
text: Neighborhoods with fewer treatment beds and hospital resources have lower median incomes — $38,000 in the Bronx versus $82,000 in Manhattan — and are filled with residents whose jobs have put them at higher risk of infection https://t.co/bIxbvuylKV https://t.co/pXR93XWsm7

name: nytimes
text: Inequality did not arrive with the virus; the divide between the haves and the have-nots has long been a part of the web of hospitals in New York City. But the pandemic exposed and amplified the inequities, according to doctors, nurses and other workers. https://t.co/bIxbvuylKV
